Posts.Content: climbergirl wrote: Hi All, I know precious little about this but I do know some places are starting to use this technology for BC. What I do know that the beam that they use has no exit path, it is targeted right into the lesion and then stops.  This is what makes it so good to use with small children! No extra scattering for small and sensitive tissues... ~climbergirl  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Has Anyone Done Proton Therapy for Rads? climbergirl climbergirl

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2007 03:49PM - edited Dec 27, 2007 03:49PM by climbergirl I actually discontinued Taxol in October because of foot muscle and lower leg issues and also because of the studies that came out about Taxol not being great for Est pos ladies.(I am Est positive) I really have an issue with the fact that this is still standard of care for most women and totally regret doing it. Only did 2 treatments but even then ended up with a slight neuropathy in both feet and have had lower leg muscle issues since October(Achilles Tendinitis.) I have gone back to my climbing and am finding that my muscles get sore not the next day but only hours later. My feet hurt constantly, not terribly but these no longer feel like my feet. Also am noticing almost arthritic like pains in the hands. This could be related to the low estrogen as well so it is hard to know...there is no way I am doing any tamoxifen while things are like this. I want my old body back and am glad that you are no longer in pain. As a yoga person I know only too well how much hip pain sucks! ~climbergirl
Posts.Title: HIP PAIN GONE tornadogirl climbergirl

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 05:53AM climbergirl wrote:  As a yoga practitioner I have always assumed that the pain on the irradiated side was not the ribs but the intercostal muscles which you need to be working and stretching *especially after radiation*....these little muscles are tight on most people and will be tight on your "good" side as well but you do not notice it because the tissue has not been damaged by radiation. Definitely try some yoga to get into that area. Keeping things stretched and moving on your treated side is key for those muscles to heal in a way that will not be as restrictive...and they will go into spasm and cause pain if they are not worked. Yes it is going to hurt a bit but with work it will not as much. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal...   www.yogajournal.com/poses/1675  Good Luck, climber girl
Posts.Title: Radiation and Rib Pain tomatojuice BarbW

Posts.Content: climbergirl wrote: Where I work @ the Broad Institute in Camb MA a Co-Worker of mine John Rinn gave a fantastic talk on non coding RNA and how it can be used in both Treatment and testing.  Sadly none of the big Pharma are interested in a test that will tell women if they REALLY need to do chemo, really need to do anything with DCIS etc. In many cases we over treat and we need to address that problem.  Please check this company out as it can help many with that decision, I wish it was around when I was diganosed 5 years ago www.mybreastcancertreatment.org/  Be well! ~Climbergirl  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2011 04:43AM climbergirl wrote: Over 5 years out w/2 pos nodes w micromatast. Est prog pos I did chemo, Mx and rads. More and more research is showing that your BC is not my BC and treatment is going to become more and more specialized to the individual. This is the case for other Cancers as well....
Posts.Title: Positive nodes with long term survival many Lily55

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 05:39PM climbergirl wrote: My Rad peeps @ Dana told me that post Mx they do not like to wait longer than 8 weeks. I am in the same boat you are on deciding if I want to do rads after my Mx on Jan 18th. I was talking to my acupuncturist about the long term toxicity with rads and the more I think about it the more I think I will not do it. A friend of mine has run into perm damage to the brachial plexus from rads. Scary stuff and it sucks. I think that with all of the breast tissue gone there is a greater chance of the field hitting the lung/heart but do not quote me. There are people here that can speak more on that. If you have nodes removed and then do the rads you do have a greater risk for lymphedema, but I do not know the percentage. Your question is a good one! ~climbergirl
Posts.Title: Rads after mastectomy vs. rads after lumpectomy? otter twink

Posts.Content: climbergirl wrote: Hi All, I have been lurking for a bit and am wondering if there are any of you out there that would in retrospect elect not to have a SNB, never mind a fully axillary? It seems that most peeps have some soreness and swelling for quite a while and then there are others that have no trouble at all. I have a great surgeon but having such an invasive diagnostic in such a nerve laden area to me is just kind of mind blowing. Given my activity level and what I do it makes me super nervous. BTW, I am both a science nerd and a yoga person and I work over at MIT at a place called the Broad Institute. The Broad was major part of the Human Genome project and we have just kicked off a ton of genomic cancer studies that should have major impact on how we get treated for this disease. We have already sequenced many tumour lines which will lead to more specific treatment someday. However, as my lumpectomy is on Tues that ain't gonna help me too much! Also if anyone could comment on what it is like to have the wire placement pre lumpectomy that would be cool as well. Are you IN the mammo machine during this? I wonder, can they do this via ultra sound instead like a core biopsy? Cheers, climbergirl Log in to post a reply

I was thinking that she might want to come up to Boston as I have had excellent treatment with Dr Gadd and know that people also love Dr. Houlihan at BI as well. Any info/experience would be appreciated! Also any other fave BC surgeons that you love would also be helpful..... Thanks, climbergirl  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Lymphedema after Rads climbergirl sccruiser

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 08:36AM climbergirl wrote: 5% percent? Having done the chemo I would not go through it for a measly 5 percent. Please make sure you look at all the possible long term effects of chemo before you undergo this....if you are opting for AC with T be aware that there is danger to your heart and all kinds of muscular/neuropathy issues with hands and feet from Taxol. I am still dealing with neuropathy SE's 7 months out. MD's tend to play all of this down..... ~Climbergirl

Posts.Title: Deciding no to a SNB? climbergirl lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2007 06:51PM climbergirl wrote: I tweaked my last two treatments of Taxol because my onc could not give me any *solid* stats that said it actually helps est pos women. I knew this from research and was having major neuropathy and joint issues. Then a study came out last week confirming my choice. Mind you another article countered that study but really did not tell me anything that changed my mind. Most likely pushed by the people that make Taxol. Joanne E~ Tell the bitchy nurse that she can comment on what you choose to do when either: A. She has Breast cancer. or B. Hell freezes over. Better yet, let me come with you and tell her myself! Doctors do indeed take orders from patients....at least the ones in my family! It is your body and your choice and the best you can do is listen to what they recommend and decide. I weary of the standard of care litany as we are seeing more and more that what is good for the majority may not be so for the individual. There was a time that docs handed out hysterectomies and cesareans to our mothers like candy. In many cases.....wrongly. If more women questioned their doctors we may eventually end up with treatments that are more geared towards quality of life. The fact that we STILL are treating BC with non specific chemo and surgery is mind boggling. ~climbergirl

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 12:00PM - edited Jan 11, 2008 12:02PM by climbergirl Ok ladies, My left Mx is for next Friday the 18th. ...what should I have on hand and what should I expect? I have two week off from the job at present. After much hand wringing I think that given my future rads treatment and need to get back to climbing ASAP that this is what it is gonna be. No recon for now. I have read that anything that buttons in the front is good....what kind of camisoles work for this straight out of the hospital?   What kind of breast form (I'm a small B)will work for wearing tank tops and what would work for climbing in the future?  I may opt to wear nothing during yoga and climbing and I will see if I can find any older threads on this as well. Thanks a ton! ~climbergirl
